mn113:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn113:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
mn113:2.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you the qualities of a true person and the qualities of an untrue person.
mn113:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
mn113:3.1: “And what is a quality of an untrue person?
mn113:3.2: Take an untrue person who has gone forth from an eminent family.
mn113:3.4: ‘I have gone forth from an eminent family, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:3.5: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:3.6: This is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:3.8: ‘It’s not because of one’s eminent family that thoughts of greed, hate, or delusion come to an end.
mn113:3.9: Even if someone has not gone forth from an eminent family,
mn113:3.10: if they practice in line with the teaching, practice properly, and live in line with the teaching, they are worthy of honor and praise for that.’
mn113:3.11: Keeping only the practice close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their eminent family.
mn113:3.12: This is a quality of a true person.
mn113:4-6.1: Furthermore, take an untrue person who has gone forth from a great family …
mn113:4-6.5: ‘I have gone forth from an extremely wealthy family, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:4-6.6: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:4-6.7: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:4-6.9: ‘It’s not because of one’s extremely wealthy family that thoughts of greed, hate, or delusion come to an end.
mn113:4-6.10: Even if someone has not gone forth from an extremely wealthy family,
mn113:4-6.11: if they practice in line with the teaching, practice properly, and live in line with the teaching, they are worthy of honor and praise for that.’
mn113:4-6.12: Keeping only the practice close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their extremely wealthy family.
mn113:4-6.13: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:7.1: Furthermore, take an untrue person who is well-known and famous.
mn113:7.3: ‘I’m well-known and famous. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’
mn113:7.4: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:7.5: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:7.7: ‘It’s not because of one’s fame that thoughts of greed, hate, or delusion come to an end.
mn113:7.8: Even if someone is not well-known and famous,
mn113:7.9: if they practice in line with the teaching, practice properly, and live in line with the teaching, they are worthy of honor and praise for that.’
mn113:7.10: Keeping only the practice close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their fame.
mn113:7.11: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:8.1: Furthermore, take an untrue person who receives robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
mn113:8.3: ‘I receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:8.4: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:8.5: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:8.7: ‘It’s not because of one’s material possessions that thoughts of greed, hate, or delusion come to an end.
mn113:8.8: Even if someone doesn’t receive robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick,
mn113:8.9: if they practice in line with the teaching, practice properly, and live in line with the teaching, they are worthy of honor and praise for that.’
mn113:8.10: Keeping only the practice close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their material possessions.
mn113:8.11: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:9.1: Furthermore, take an untrue person who is very learned …
mn113:10.1: who is an expert in the monastic law …
mn113:13.1: who is a rag robe wearer …
mn113:15.1: who stays at the root of a tree …
mn113:16-20.1: who stays in a charnel ground …
mn113:16-20.2: who stays in the open air …
mn113:16-20.4: who sleeps wherever they lay their mat …
mn113:16-20.5: who eats in one sitting per day.
mn113:16-20.7: ‘I eat in one sitting per day, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:16-20.8: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:16-20.9: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:16-20.11: ‘It’s not because of eating in one sitting per day that thoughts of greed, hate, or delusion come to an end.
mn113:16-20.12: Even if someone eats in more than one sitting per day,
mn113:16-20.13: if they practice in line with the teaching, practice properly, and live in line with the teaching, they are worthy of honor and praise for that.’
mn113:16-20.14: Keeping only the practice close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their eating in one sitting per day.
mn113:16-20.15: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:21.1: Furthermore, take an untrue person who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn113:21.3: ‘I have attained the first absorption, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:21.4: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:21.5: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:21.7: ‘The Buddha has spoken of not identifying even with the attainment of the first absorption.
mn113:21.8: For whatever they imagine it is, it turns out to be something else.’
mn113:21.9: Keeping only non-identification close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their attainment of the first absorption.
mn113:21.10: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:22-24.1: Furthermore, take an untrue person who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption …
mn113:22-24.5: ‘I have attained the fourth absorption, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:22-24.6: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:22-24.7: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:22-24.9: ‘The Buddha has spoken of not identifying even with the attainment of the fourth absorption.
mn113:22-24.10: For whatever they imagine it is, it turns out to be something else.’
mn113:22-24.11: Keeping only non-identification close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their attainment of the fourth absorption.
mn113:22-24.12: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:25.1: Furthermore, take someone who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space …
mn113:28.1: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn113:28.3: ‘I have attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, unlike these other mendicants.’
mn113:28.4: And they glorify themselves and put others down on account of that.
mn113:28.5: This too is a quality of an untrue person.
mn113:28.7: ‘The Buddha has spoken of not identifying even with the attainment of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn113:28.8: For whatever they imagine it is, it turns out to be something else.’
mn113:28.9: Keeping only non-identification close to their heart, they don’t glorify themselves and put others down on account of their attainment of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
mn113:28.10: This too is a quality of a true person.
mn113:29.1: Furthermore, take a true person who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
mn113:29.2: This is a mendicant who does not identify with anything, does not identify regarding anything, does not identify through anything.”
mn113:29.3: That is what the Buddha said.
mn113:29.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
